ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I was able to refine my storytelling skills and learn a little bit about video editing

I learned how archives play a role in my personal identity. We did a lot of processing for our film. The class wasn't focused on film technique as much as the process of how we consider and create our films.

Because this class provided a safe, experimental space, I felt that I could be my full self as an artist. In this environment, I was able to work on my communication skills through explaining my idea or offering feedback to everyone else. I also learned this through time since we were often limited by it.

In this class I learned how to utilize family, found, and public archives and worked to develop my filmmaking style. We analyzed films made by prominent filmmakers and tales with them during class in order to gain exposure to a bunch of different filmmaking styles and ways to incorporate archives into documentary and creative films.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I didn't see any weaknesses to the course. This course was a truly beacon of light to me - I learned to trust my inner voice, and that the process of making something is what matters - the skill will come along the way.

The strength was that I learned a lot without being too stressed, which is very rare for a class. I was thoroughly engaged, as we mainly held discussions every class and watched many films. My classmates and I were able to open up about our personal lives and be vulnerable.
The weakness is that I was slightly disconcerted about the appropriateness of the class. There were some films and readings that were inappropriate to me, but that is compared to my own level of sensitivity.

The only weakness I can think of is that the class was quite long considering virtual learning. We usually took 2 breaks which ranged from 5-10 minutes but  I was still usually very tired once we reached halfway, since I also had a seminar beforehand.

The biggest strength was the constant feedback we received not only from our professor and teaching fellow, but also from classmates. Although all of our assignments were individual projects, the class felt very collaborative because of the amount of time we were given to brainstorm with each other during class.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It was overall successful, all things considered. We had designated time for breaks that helped with zoom fatigue, and having readings and films to go over on our own time helped as well.

It was successful to hold a film class, because screen sharing wasn't too bad and discussions were not greatly hindered. However, the amount of time was a challenge, as it was hard to stare at a screen for three hours. Overall, it was as good as it could be during the pandemic.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes. We truly undervalue lived experience in our storytelling and this course truly cultivates how one can tell their own story, but also how their story is informed by, and reflective of, greater cultural issues. Also it offers a magnificent shift from the white canon, by offering resources that I wouldn't be able to find, which we all truly need.

Yes, I would. Even if you do not have any experience with filmmaking, that is totally fine. You will have to navigate a lot of the editing parts on your own if you are up to that, but the professor is more concerned about the effort you make to know more about yourself.

Yes! I came in with no filmmaking experience and now am considering it as a new medium to explore. You don't need to know any technical skills. You learn along the way. I recommend it even more for people who don't have filmmaking experience, actually, but who are still interested in the subject matter. You skills will translate and it might open you up to a new passion!

I would highly recommend this class. We watched a lot of amazing films and got to speak with the majority of the filmmakers throughout the course of the semester. I feel like I was given enough space to experiment and develop my filmmaking practice over the course of this semester. I had filmmaking experience before taking this course, but it was definitely not necessary! This class was the first time many of my classmates had ever worked with film, but because of the easygoing and supportive nature of the class (completely fostered by Professor Harris and our tf Lauren) everyone was able to produce three solid videos that we were all proud of by the end of the semester.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Films and readings as well on our own time
We mainly had discussions, sometimes with guest speakers. We also had screenings of student films.
